thread.title: Tears of relief as childcare centre land to be transferred back to Ministry of Education
thread.title_full: Tears of relief as childcare centre land to be transferred back to Ministry of Education

author: Laura Dooney
title: Tears of relief as childcare centre land to be transferred back to Ministry of Education
text:
Tears of relief as childcare centre land to be transferred back to Ministry of Education LAURA DOONEY Last updated 17:19, February 8 2017 SUPPLIED 
Campbell Kindergarten in Karori has been operating for more than 30 years. 
Two early childhood education centres in Karori will stay right where they are, after a decision to transfer some of Victoria University's Karori campus back to the Ministry of Education. 
Since the university made the decision in August last year to sell the former teacher training campus, the Karori community had been concerned the site for Campbell Kindergarten and Karori Kids would be sold, and the centres left homeless. 
Acting Secretary for Education Kim Shannon said the ministry was working through a process to transfer the land on which Karori Kids and Campbell Kindergarten are based from the university back to the ministry. CAMERON BURNELL/FAIRFAX NZ 
The decision was made by Victoria University to sell the campus in August last year. 
"It's a complex situation and we are working through the details," Shannon said. 
READ MORE: 
"We recognise that the children and families of Karori Kids and Campbell Kindergarten have been through a great deal of uncertainty. Our aim is to ensure their existing tenancy arrangements can continue." CAMERON BURNELL/FAIRFAX NZ 
What will happen to the rest of the site is yet to be worked out. 
Whanau Manaaki Kindergartens chief executive Amanda Coulson said teachers and parents had burst into tears of relief on hearing the news on Wednesday. 
Coulson said everyone was relieved common sense had prevailed, and the services could get on and continue to provide for the community. 
"We're feeling very reassured. 
"We thought it should happen. It is the right thing to do, it is great the ministry and Victoria University have seen that it's the right thing to do." Ad Feedback 
The two sites were included in the merger between the Wellington College of Education and Victoria University in 2004, and the title transfer that came in 2014. 
Victoria University agreed transferring the land back to the Ministry of Education was the right thing to do, Shannon said. - Stuff
